div1.p: Kean talks about his recent retirement from the U. S. Army. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Leonard Wood, September 15, 1924
div1.opener:
September 15, 1924.
Major General Leonard Wood, USA.,
Governor General,
Manila, P.I.
My dear General Wood:
div1.p:
I have just received and read with the
greatest gratification your very cordial and
flattering letter on my retirement. Of course I
regretted retiring as most men do whose hearts
are still with the service but the drop into the
retired list has been softened by the kindness of
my good friends like yourself. The Medical Offi-
cers of the First Corps Area gave me a wonderful
dinner on July 2nd at Longfellow's, or rather Mr.
Ford's, Wayside Inn at South Sudebury at which
they made speeches to me and said so many flatter-
ing things that I thought I would certainly have
to get a hat a size larger.

Cornelia joins me in love to you both.
We have come to Washington to live and have bought
a little house about as big as your fist in
Georgetown. We both regretted greatly to leave
our good friends in Boston and Cornelia was quite
disconsolate for a while but now she has gotten
so interested in fixing up her house that I think
(over)
she is getting reconciled to living here. What
brought me here was the Editorship of The Mili-
tary Surgeon to which I had been elected about a
year ago and which was held for me until my retire-
ment. I find the work of Secretary-Editor very
interesting and engrossing although it is far from
remunerative proposition at present.
div1.closer:
With cordial best wishes, I am
Always your friend and admirer, J. R. Kean Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired,
Secretary-Treasurer.
JRK/W
